body: Were you able to resolve this?  I have the same problem with release-0_13_0.

Which operating system are you on?
Is Python installed?

On Sat, Feb 27, 2016 at 12:04 PM Haisam Ido notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Were you able to resolve this? I have the same problem with release-0_13_0.
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/4878#issuecomment-189715264.
I get the above error on Centos7 and AWS Linux and yes I have python installed.

What happens if you run:

```
test/core/httpcli/test_server.py --ssl
```

Interesting!

```
test/core/httpcli/test_server.py --ssl
/home/haisamido/Development/staging/grpc/src/core/tsi/test_creds/server1.pem
server running on port 10080

```

and I am able to

```
telnet localhost 10080
Trying 127.0.0.1...
Connected to localhost.
Escape character is '^]'.
```

Weird. Can you post the log of doing:

make clean
make httpscli_test
bins/opt/httpscli_test

TLDR: I think that it's not anything broken with gRPC per-se.

Suspect the OpenSSL that's linked with Python doesn't support the cypher
suites that we need.

This test runs a Python web server that it tries to connect to via HTTP/0.9
- as a test that we have an avenue to fetch OAUTH tokens.

Probably the correct answer is to disable this test on this platform, or to
develop a HTTP/0.9 server in C that we can link with our SSL implementation
and test against.

What is your version of Python ?

Python 2 has by default notoriously old OpenSSL bindings (because Python 2 is itself, old), hence the reason of existence of pyOpenSSL.

```
$ python
Python 2.7.6 (default, Jun 22 2015, 17:58:13)
[GCC 4.8.2] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ssl
>>> ssl.OPENSSL_VERSION
'OpenSSL 1.0.1f 6 Jan 2014'
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv3
1
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_SSLv23
2
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1
3
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_1
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'PROTOCOL_TLSv1_1'
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'module' object has no attribute 'PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2'

$ python3
Python 3.4.3 (default, Oct 14 2015, 20:28:29)
[GCC 4.8.4] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ssl
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_1
4
>>> ssl.PROTOCOL_TLSv1_2
5
```

Another answer would maybe to see if pyOpenSSL could be used to overcome the shortcomings of python2's ssl.
